slides.title: Forms of Employee Behavior
content: Organizations depend on employee behavior that contributes directly or indirectly to success.
Performance behaviors are work-related actions contributing to productivity and accomplishment of tasks.
Organizational citizenship behaviors reflect positive contributions made with no direct bottom-line impact.
Counterproductive behaviors include actions that detract from organizational performance (e.g., absenteeism).
Managers must recognize and cultivate beneficial behaviors while minimizing counterproductive ones.
slides.script: Welcome everyone! We'll begin our discussion on Chapter 8 by exploring the various forms of employee behavior that significantly impact an organization's performance. We will examine positive behaviors like performance and citizenship, as well as counterproductive behaviors that must be addressed.

slides.title: Individual Differences Matter
content: Employee behavior is influenced by individual differences that make each person unique at work.
Personality traits influence interactions, decision-making, and job performance across industries.
Understanding individual differences improves matching people to roles where they can perform effectively.
Recognizing different attitudes and needs promotes inclusion, improving motivation and performance.
slides.script: Now let's take a look at a critical aspect of understanding employee behavior—the recognition and appreciation of individual differences. We will dive into how personality traits and varying attitudes impact the workplace, shaping interactions, decisions, and job performance.

slides.title: The 'Big Five' Personality Traits
content: Agreeableness: How well individuals get along with and cooperate with others in the workplace.
Conscientiousness: Reflects organization, persistence, responsibility, and dependability in carrying out tasks.
Emotionality: Indicates positivity/negativity in one's behaviors toward others.
Extraversion: Comfort level with relationships, sociability, and new connection willingness.
Openness: Characterizes receptiveness to new ideas, flexibility in beliefs, and willingness to change.
slides.script: This slide introduces the 'Big Five' personality traits, which are key indicators of individual behavior in the workplace. Understanding where employees fall on each of these traits provides valuable insights into their interactions, work styles, and potential job roles.

slides.title: Other Key Personality Attributes
content: Locus of Control: Internal (belief in personal influence) versus External (belief in luck/fate)
Self-Efficacy: The extent to which one believes in their own ability to complete a task.
Authoritarianism: Degree to which a person believes power and status differences are appropriate.
Machiavellianism: Behavior directed at gaining power and controlling others' behavior in the company.
Self-Esteem: Individual's sense of worth and deservingness, which influences job and role choices.
slides.script: In addition to the 'Big Five', several other personality traits are vital in understanding and predicting employee behavior. These are locus of control, self-efficacy, authoritarianism, Machiavellianism, and self-esteem. These attributes significantly impact workplace dynamics and individual success.

slides.title: Attitudes and Their Components
content: Attitudes reflect one’s beliefs and feelings about specific situations, ideas, or other individuals.
Cognition involves the knowledge a person possesses, which may or may not align with reality.
Affect is a person’s feelings and emotions that guide their behavior in both rational and irrational ways.
Intention guides a person's behavior, although this doesn't always translate into action.
Cognitive dissonance arises when cognitions conflict, causing discomfort and potentially influencing behavior.
slides.script: Moving beyond personality traits, let's examine attitudes, which express our beliefs and feelings about specific situations and people. Understanding the role of cognition, affect, and intention can be useful for predicting and managing employee responses to company policies and procedures.

slides.title: Matching People and Jobs
content: Organizations benefit from effective alignment of their employees to specific roles and their jobs.
The psychological contract outlines expectations for what employees contribute and what they receive.
Fairness in the psychological contract affects job satisfaction and willingness to comply with leadership.
Person-Job fit—the extent to which a person's contributions and the organization's inducements align.
slides.script: This slide explores the concept of 'matching people and jobs', which highlights the importance of aligning employee contributions with organizational inducements to enhance job satisfaction and performance. We will see how psychological contracts and the person-job fit play critical roles in creating a harmonious and productive workplace.

slides.title: Classical Theory and Early Behavioral Theory
content: Classical Theory: Assumes that employees are motivated solely by money and that pay drives production.
Time-and-Motion Studies sought to maximize efficiency through job task analysis and pay.
The Hawthorne effect showed that attention and engagement improved output, independent of working conditions.
The focus shifted towards a better understanding of human relations to raise worker performance.
slides.script: Now let's take a brief historical review of the evolving understanding of employee motivation. We'll start with the Classical Theory, which emphasizes financial incentives, and then transition into the Early Behavioral Theory, discussing the ground-breaking Hawthorne studies which highlighted the importance of attention and positive human relations in boosting employee performance.

slides.title: Human Resources Model: Theory X and Y
content: Theory X: Managers who believe people dislike work, lack ambition, and need control to be productive.
Theory Y: Managers who believe people are energetic, growth-oriented, and self-motivated to be productive.
McGregor believed that managers accepting Theory Y assumptions were more likely to have motivated employees.
It's an oversimplified model but highlights the different assumptions a leader makes.
slides.script: Let's continue our review of historical methods to employee behavior. Here we will review McGregor's Theory X and Theory Y that classified managers based on their beliefs about employees' inherent attitudes towards work, revealing how management assumptions profoundly influence worker motivation and job performance.

slides.title: Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs Model
content: Proposed that people satisfy needs in a hierarchy: Physiological, Security, Social, Esteem, Self-Actualization.
Lower-level needs drive behavior until satisfied.  Progressing up the hierarchy depends on satisfaction.
Once needs are met, they cease to be motivators unless lower needs become threatened.
Framework for understanding the interplay of various needs within an organization.
slides.script: Now let's move on to Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs, a foundational concept explaining how people prioritize various needs in their lives. Understanding the role each of these plays can help managers devise effective motivational strategies.

slides.title: Herzberg's Two-Factor Theory
content: Job satisfaction/dissatisfaction depends on 2 factors: hygiene factors and motivating factors.
Hygiene factors (working conditions, pay) produce feelings of dissatisfaction when unacceptable.
Motivating factors (achievement, recognition) lead to true satisfaction and increased motivation.
A manager must improve hygiene factors and offer motivating ones to maximize satisfaction and motivation.
slides.script: Building on the earlier theories, we will explore Herzberg's Two-Factor Theory, emphasizing the distinct roles of hygiene factors and motivating factors in determining job satisfaction. This theory suggests that a two-step approach is needed: one to ensure an absence of dissatisfaction, and another to actively boost satisfaction and motivation.

slides.title: Key Acquired Needs
content: Need for Achievement: Individual's desire to accomplish goals effectively.
Need for Affiliation: Drive for positive, supportive relationships.
Need for Power: Desire to control the environment and resources in order to be successful.
Balance and use of these traits determines a manager's effectiveness at improving outcomes.
Organizations should foster each of these traits in order to succeed.
slides.script: This slide introduces three 'Acquired Needs'—the need for achievement, affiliation, and power. These drive key aspects of behavior in the workplace and determine how workers pursue goals and interact with colleagues. Understanding these can help manage staff more effectively.

slides.title: Expectancy Theory
content: Motivation is a function of perceived chances of obtaining desired rewards.
Effort-Performance Issue: Employee's perception that effort will lead to high performance.
Performance-Reward Issue: Employee's perception that high performance will lead to rewards.
Rewards-Personal Goals Issue:  Rewards must be valuable and fulfill an employee's personal aspirations.
This model illustrates various issues that can be considered by employees.
slides.script: Now we're going to study contemporary views of worker motivation. Let's start with Expectancy Theory, which suggests that employees are motivated to work towards rewards they desire if they believe they have a reasonable chance of attaining them.

slides.title: Equity Theory
content: Focuses on how employees evaluate treatment relative to that of others.
Employees assess their inputs (effort) to their outcomes (rewards).
They form a ratio and compare this with others. Feelings of equity influence motivation.
Inequitable treatment can result in seeking a raise, lower effort, quitting the job, and/or other problems.
slides.script: Another contemporary view of employee behavior can be seen with Equity Theory, which emphasizes the social aspects of motivation by examining how individuals perceive fairness in the distribution of rewards.

slides.title: Techniques for Enhancing Motivation
content: Reinforcement/Behavior Modification: Uses rewards for desirable and punishments for undesirable behaviors.
Using Goals: setting motivational and achievable performance standards.
Participative Management and Empowerment: Giving employees a voice in company management to encourage productivity.
Job Enrichment and Job Redesign: Changing and improving the value-added function of specific tasks.
Modified Work Schedules and Alternative Workplaces: Improve motivation via employee-friendly work arrangement.
slides.script: Finally, let's wrap up this chapter by reviewing various strategies and techniques organizations employ to improve employee motivation and create a more engaging and productive work environment. We'll review reinforcement, goal setting, participative management, job enrichment, and modified work schedules.
